title: Do humans by default tend to think members of their own group are superior to other groups, and it is only through deeper reflection that they come to realize this may not be true? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think the history of mankind has shown that people do seek to belong to groups based upon their similarities with other people, and to promote and defend and have a feeling of belonging to that group. Sociologists used to call this “in-group cohesiveness”. This feeling of being part of something bigger than yourself has allowed people to come together for mutual benefits and defense from harm that individuals could not do on their own. Thus, people have historically congregated in villages, towns and cities for mutual support, mutual benefits and shared belief/value systems. This is not anything evil in itself — it shows that humans, and other animals, have the capacity to bond together for mutual benefit. The threat comes not from pride in one’s group but from the belief that one’s group is superior to all others and should impose its will against other groups. Rather than live-and-let-live, some groups can be motivated to conquer others and brutalize them. Simply feeling pride in one’s group is not a negative thing; it is when that pride is used to motivate one’s group to seize and plunder other groups that the problems mount. I don’t subscribe to the view that patriotism or nationalism are essentially bad. Pride in one’s country allows people to risk and lose their lives for a greater cause, a greater good (e.g., fighting the evil of Hitler and the Nazis). Without that group solidarity, people are more likely to think only of their individual interests and not respond to the common good that requires their sacrifices. Cheering one’s country in the Olympics or other international competitions is not evil — it reinforces the pride in one’s group that any successful group must have. Yes, that national pride can be subverted for evil purposes, but pride and patriotism alone are not problematic. I believe that most people are curious about other groups and their cultures and traditions. People leave the comfort of familiar surroundings to travel to other countries because they want to experience and enjoy those cultural differences, the sights, the sounds, the tastes. Most are open to learning and appreciating the achievements of other people, but that does not mean they lose pride in their own country and people. Even US, whose people have been encouraged to see themselves and their country as “best”, can appreciate other countries and peoples, and that has increasingly occurred during the past 50 years. Yet, we still chant “USA! USA!” when our countrymen succeed, and that doesn’t mean we hold low regard for others — we celebrate because we know how difficult it can be to prevail and how strong our competition.

Not necessarily. The default, I’d imagine, would lie more along knowing one way to do something (and the persons doing it) and believing it’s the only way (without necessarily thinking too hard about what options might be out there). More like «we do what we do and know who we know because that’s how we do it», not because it’s inherently better, but because that’s how it is. Not everything’s (though plenty would be) a competition of superiority.
